skill.name: specs-creator
skill.description: Creates comprehensive Product Requirements Documents (PRDs), Technical Specifications, and UX Specifications from feature descriptions. Guides users through structured documentation workflows with template compliance validation.
skill.summary: Creates structured PRDs, tech specs, and UX specifications from feature requirements
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: Documentation generation skill with no security concerns. All 241 static findings are false positives triggered by pattern matching in markdown templates and documentation files. The skill contains Python validation scripts and markdown templates for specification creation. No actual code execution, sensitive data access, or malicious patterns present.

content.value_statement: Teams struggle to produce consistent, comprehensive documentation. This skill generates standardized PRDs, technical specs, and UX specifications following proven templates, ensuring nothing is missed and stakeholders receive clear, actionable documents.
actual_capabilities: Generates Product Requirements Documents (PRDs) from feature descriptions
Creates Technical Specifications with architecture and implementation details
Produces UX Specifications including user flows and accessibility requirements
Validates specifications against template compliance rules
Enforces dependency chains between specification types
Saves all outputs to designated specs directory
limitations: Does not write or modify actual code implementation
Cannot create specs without user-provided feature requirements
Does not overwrite existing specs without explicit approval
Does not make architectural decisions beyond documentation scope

use_cases.title: New Feature Documentation
use_cases.description: Product managers provide feature requirements and receive a complete PRD with user stories, acceptance criteria, and success metrics.

use_cases.title: Technical Architecture Planning
use_cases.description: Engineering teams generate detailed technical specifications including component diagrams, API contracts, and deployment procedures.

use_cases.title: Design Specification Handoff
use_cases.description: Designers create UX specifications documenting user flows, accessibility requirements, and interaction patterns for engineering implementation.

prompt_templates.title: Basic PRD Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PRD for [product name]. The feature is [brief feature description]. Include user stories, acceptance criteria, and success metrics.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick PRD generation for straightforward features

prompt_templates.title: Full Technical Specification
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a technical specification for [project name]. The requirements are: [list requirements]. Include architecture overview, API endpoints, data models, and deployment instructions.
prompt_templates.scenario: Complete technical documentation for development teams

prompt_templates.title: UX Design Specification
prompt_templates.prompt: Create UX specifications for [feature/screen name]. The user flows are: [describe flows]. Include accessibility requirements, interaction patterns, and component states.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Documentation Suite
prompt_templates.prompt: Create specifications for [feature] following the dependency chain. First create the PRD, then generate tech specs, and finally create UX specifications. Feature requirements: [detailed requirements].
prompt_templates.scenario: Full documentation package with all three specification types

output_examples.input: Create a PRD for a user notification system that includes email, push, and in-app notifications.
output: A unified notification system supporting email, push, and in-app channels with user preference management.
As a user, I want to manage notification preferences so that I control which notifications I receive.

output_examples.input: Create tech specs for an API Gateway with rate limiting and authentication.
output: The API Gateway serves as the single entry point for all client requests...

best_practices: Provide detailed feature requirements including edge cases and error scenarios
Review generated specifications for accuracy before implementation
Follow the dependency chain: PRD â†’ Tech Specs â†’ UX Specs for complex features
Use validation scripts to ensure template compliance before sharing documents
anti_patterns: Requesting specs without clear feature requirements or success criteria
Skipping validation and using non-compliant specifications
Overwriting existing specs without proper backup or version control
Expecting architectural decisions without providing constraints or context

faq.question: What specifications can this skill create?
faq.answer: This skill creates three types of specifications: Product Requirements Documents (PRDs), Technical Specifications, and UX Specifications. Each follows a standardized template with required and optional sections.

faq.question: Does this skill write code?
faq.answer: No, this skill only creates documentation. It explicitly prohibits writing or modifying code implementation. The output is purely specification documents for other team members to use.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for existing projects?
faq.answer: Yes, you can create specifications for existing features. Provide the feature description and any relevant context about the current implementation.

faq.question: What is the dependency chain?
faq.answer: The skill follows a dependency chain: app-vision.md â†’ prd.md â†’ tech-specs.md â†’ ux.md. This ensures documentation builds progressively from product vision through technical implementation to design details.

faq.question: How does validation work?
faq.answer: The skill runs validation scripts that check specifications against template requirements. This ensures all required sections are present and properly formatted before the document is finalized.

faq.question: Where are specifications saved?
faq.answer: Specifications are saved to a designated specs/ directory within your project. The exact location depends on your project structure and will be included in the skill's output report.
